reviewText:
Pyrite Heart's an interesting VN because it seems like a lot of other otome games, but when you get into it, it lacks the personality or flair of those games. Whether it's because the set-up steers into the inciting argument within three lines or whether it's because the protagonist actively picks a fight with everyone and everything constantly, Pyrite Heart feels like it's missing something – and it may be heart.

To me it feels like Pyrite Heart took the easy way out on every turn. Instead of setting up the princess' personality at home, it immediately throws her into school. Instead of creating an opportunity for a natural relationship to happen, the princess forces it, attacking the first guy she sees, making him stand out as the main guy instantly but obviously. Of course, the protagonist is a very aggressive character, and that would be fine if she didn't feel like a shallow take on tsundere with more stubborn traits and an inferiority complex added in quickly. The love interests feel similarly shallow, with the option of either perfect-but-sensitive class president or sporty-and-mostly-loyal secret servant from home.

While the dare's time limit of a week is realistic for some silly dare, it takes way too much away from what could happen in the actual story. Drama is quick and incredibly easy to see coming, and the whole premise of royalty is kind of confusing since it's presented as the Japanese Imperial House but seems a lot like a take on western royalty.

Simple choices and good art be damned. This game is too quick to jump on reasons and challenges to give purpose and drive to its events, and in doing that leaves out some of the most important things you could find in an otome game: a moment of sincerity, a feeling of getting closer to someone, a semblance of fun.

reviewText:
Firstly, I play quite a few dating sims and visual novels so I have some basis of comparison. This game feels like it wasted potential. With solid artwork this game is very visually appealing but that's about where it ends in terms of good points. In one sitting of about an hour I beat the entire game and got what I assume to be all the endings and paths. Two good endings each ending with one of the males and the alone ending. Mind you I had the game skip all seen text but it's doubtful anyone would want to read it again. Ahri the main character has serious character flaws that seem to resolve too quickly. When they say you're spending a week out of the castle, you literally spend a week discovering your flaws and fixing them to a degree. While the dialogue can be interesting the characters just seem under developed. They're not horrible but it feels like one added bucket of water to a shallow pool of water in terms of depth of character.

Overall for the price and play time, even on sale I would not get this game. It's far too short with only about 5-8 choices to make. From what I can tell there's only one or two choices that will determine which of the two male characters you end up with. It's also obvious which choice to pick to get a good reaction from the guy. Just having two guys is also dull and boring. You don't even get a make friend option. So basically you spend a week falling in love or realizing you have feelings for a servant and then devote your life to them. Uh-huh... Sounds like high school alright...

Basically, while this game is cute and has amazing artwork, you're better off looking at screenshots for that. Save your money and maybe it will be in a bundle or something soon.

The good:    Visual appearance: A fairly high amount of CGs for such a short game, and quality ones at that. The art department is solid, nothing to complain about it; bishies, check; mandatory cute kitten, check; good backgrounds, check.

Scales well all the way up to 1080p in fullscreenmode, perhaps higher, haven't tested that.
Steam cards, I guess.
The bad:    Very short, expect to finish a playthrough and still have cards to drop (well, perhaps not now with the 2 hours rule, but back when I played this it took me two playthroughs and then some idling to get the cards, that's how short this is).
The script: somehow clichéd, though less so than others thanks to the protagonist's personality. A tsundere protagonist is not something everyone will stomach, and many of the lines used to convey that feel forced or just ridiculous.
You only get to pick one out of two routes, each has two endings and all end rather abruptly. Thus, there's very little replayability value. ERRATA: There are actually six endings, as pointed out by Alexia in the comments (who also made a  handy guide about it). Even so, I feel that the replayability value remains quite low.
As others pointed out, this used to be free and voice-acted. This is no longer the case on the Steam version.
This is a very subjective opinion, but I found the protagonist unsufferable. Not because I dislike the tsundere archetype, but because I really found her unsufferable.

A short otome VN which does its job relatively well but feels rushed and leaves you with a they could've put more into this" kind of feeling. To recommend

A cute and interesting game with a really gorgeous art style - though still a little lacking.

Its not the best written game either, the dialogue could have had a little bit more attention thrown in to make it seem less stiff, but to each their own. I feel if this was a longer game with more character choices I could see myself being a bigger fan of the franchise, but it is a lovely VN for people who don't enjoy longer ones or those just starting out with the genre.

reviewText:
Ah man, Anime games.

Seems like Valve finally realized that there’s a whole market of games they’ve been missing out on because visual novels and the like have been flooding the Steam store lately.
Well, either that or Gaben finally found his passion for anime like Nisekoi, Kiss x Sis, To Love-Ru and other Harem anime bull excrements, which in turn lead to his sudden interest in otome games.

Pyrite Heart is one of those anime games.

You play as Ahri, princess of wherever this game takes place. Being the competition seeking girl she is, she makes a bet with her brother that she can go to a normal school for a week, just like the “commoners” do, instead of being home taught, like usual.
Yada yada yada, at school she soon finds a rival, Ryuu, the class president. Her servant, Kenta, is also here because her brother sent him to take care of her and now you gotta pick which one of those two hot guys’ lips you want to kiss.

The two guys are pretty cute. Good picks, if I do say so myself.

Ahri though, is one of the most annoying characters I’ve ever seen in a video game or visual novel. She's self-centered, sassy, selfish and, well, overall just a female dog.

Now, you might be saying right now, “But Fruitsniffer, Ahri’s a Tsundere. That’s what makes Tsunderes so cute!”.
But I say no. Just because your character’s a bootyhole doesn’t mean that she’s a Tsundere. That’s not how it works...

Okay, maybe that’s exactly how it works but that doesn’t change the fact that your main character is still an annoying piece of excrement and I don’t want to play as her.
I mean, I’d be lying if I said that there’s no character development at all. It does get better... eventually.

Alright, maybe I’m being a bit too harsh though. Ahri definitely has her cute side and can be an ok person. It just takes a while until you get to see that side of her.

The writing was just ok. Nothing special but definitely not vomit inducing either. There was some dialogue that was pretty cheesy but I guess that’s expectable when you’re playing an otome visual novel.
The main problem I had with the writing is that it's just nothing new. We've seen a story like this in so many other otome visual novels that it gets old eventually and a bit boring I guess.

The art is pretty good and there were some nice CG scenes.

The game itself is actually pretty short. I managed to get both main endings in about 1 and a half hour. In that short time the visual novel managed to get pretty emotional though and I guess it somehow touched me. Maybe I was just caught off guard by Ahri occasionally not being a total female dog though.


To summarize, Pyrite Heart is an ok visual novel with ok writing and pretty neat art. It's just nothing new, to be honest. The main character makes or breaks the visual novel for you and if you can’t deal with her attitude, this game is definitely nothing for you.
If you think Tsunderes are cute though and like it when anime girls are bootyholes to the love interests, I think you’re gonna like this one.

Oh, and one more thing:
When you buy the game on steam, you get an exclusive digital hug pillow of one of the love interests, which you can print on a pillow cover. Who wouldn’t want that?


So, Should you play Pyrite Heart?

Mmmmh... Yeah. I guess. If that’s your kind of thing. And if not, at least get it for the sexy pillow cover.

I should probably start by explaining that I am new and mainly clueless to the ideals of anime. As my first foray into an animation style that apparantly cause dispondant teenagers to disown their own culutre and declare themselves japaneese, I was underwhelmed.

Essentially, my understanding of anime is that busty girls with odd coloured hair and no resemblance to asain or american females, fight monsters while equipped with revealling mech suits. I'm also privy to the knowlege that there is a large amount of dark themes, surpirse twists, impossbly hard to remember names and the ever famous tentacle monsters. This game has none of that. This was 30 minutes of disapointment.

What I got was an adventure that comprised of reading a book worth of dialouge ( I know now that it is something refered to as graphic novel game, but that doens't derive from the fact that it is a game and should at least have some function of interactibillity). If your game is going to comprise mainly of dialouge, atleast make the dialouge...good. It was superficial at best, forced if you will. They just pushed the ideal that our main character, is smart, determined and a strong independant female without giving us an actual reason to believe it.

I counted about 3 options of choice throughtout the game. Do I stay to play basketball, how do I answer a quiz and do I hand him the pan of baked goods. Do I? Do I even care by this point? So far I've read my way through a week of her school life and as far as sexual appeal of the game goes... its lacking. I'm assuming this is an age friendly version of anime, or the rumors I have been hearing about the representation of females in animet have been false.

At the end of the day, it leaves a bitter taste. Missed oppurtunites of choice and interactibillity which would have been welcome in the plethora of text. I wasn't entirely sure what I was getting myself into when I first bought this game considering it original had mixed reviews back when I bought it but I'm glad to see that it's mostly got a positive response because this game was really fun and does deserve that. I have a soft spot for tsundere protagonists so maybe I'm a little biased but I found Ahri's tsun to dere transformation adorable especially in Ryuu's route, not to say that Kenta's wasn't just as good but I think favourite routes are normally down to personal preference. I don't think a route with the brother woul dhave gone amiss but not everyone likes that whole route's subtext.

I think the art for the game is some of the best I've seen in an otome game made in the west but I'm pretty sure other reviews have mentioned this and how well it's all been done so I'll leave that where it is and say the CG's in the game are just as beautiful as the sprite art and for such a short game I was suprised at just how many CG's there actually were.

The music is nothing too spectacular but good enough to warrant a mention and how quickly it can set a mood. After checking this game on VNDB I was told that this game was voiced but there were no voices on the version I got so unfortunately I have no comment to say on that.

The character of Ahri can be hilarious to watch if you likes tsun's that is, meaning she will be arrogant quite a bit (she pulls the Tiny Tyrranical Tsundere Grade S part very well, dont know what I mean? Tv tropes it) and be aloof and cold to the class or the guy you chose not to pursue but when paired with a guy this is were the dialogue and story shine~ The banter and just the backwards and forwards between the duo has left me laughing so hard at times. There are some very legit sad and heartfelt moments in the game including Ahri but it was a nice addition to this game and stopped it being an entirely rom-com based game but not enough to shadow over that.

I think that if a little extra time was added at the beginning of the game to establish more about Ahri and her life then the game would have been more immersive but for what we got I think it's worth the price, also is it just me or does Ahri look a bit like Nyotalia England?

To get all possible endings you are looking at approxmiately one hour of playtime. Total. Perhaps I would be more forgiving/interested if I wasn't so bored of overdone anime tropes, so if you still enjoy the tsundere thing and don't expect anything other than nice art you might enjoy this game, considering the low price.

reviewText:
This was an interesting otome game but not exactly in a good way...

Backstory: Ahri is a smart yet selfish princess to a land and is challenged (more or less) by her princely brother to last in the outside world for 1 week. With that, she heads to a normal school where she instantly wants to challange the smartest and most popular guy in school since she is used to being the smartest at the palace. Also, she finds out her brother sent in her most trusted servant to keep an eye on her. In this week, she either falls for her first ever rival or the servant she never realizes she's needed. Does she win the bet with her brother?

Overall, this was a decent otome game. With only 4 characters (at least with pictures) and 2 options, it's not a long game to do. I did this for almost 2 hours and did 3 of the routes (there is probably a good, great, and bad ending to each guy), but that's stretching it since I decided to make it fun with voice acting. Story is nothing new, but it could surfice for some people. The main character at the beginning annoyed me to no end, but she has great character development by the midway point. There was also something off putting with one of the routes, since she met one guy earlier that week and is in love already in one ending. The other guy makes sense with their backstory, but not the other guy and her. It's not all bad. With that character development, some humor, and the beautiful artwork, it still makes a decent game. I would just suggest getting it on sale (probably over half priced) to get your money's worth.
